stream_context.summary: Kaze designs and creates the blockout for the underground section of the game's oil rig level. Key activities include laying out platforming challenges, implementing a new window effect to see the level above, finding appropriate textures, and discussing game difficulty, team contributions, and his personal philosophies on various topics.

development_findings.summary: The project is described as being near completion, with only four main courses and some additional side levels remaining to be developed.
development_findings.quote: we got four courses left after this and some side levels

development_findings.summary: A new level idea was spontaneously conceived during the stream, which would use a specific rendering technique (a flame buffer with a transparent clear color) to create a unique motion blur visual effect.
development_findings.quote: A level with flame buffer is only cleared with transparent black to get a blur effect.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is consciously trying to make the game's difficulty more accessible, having learned from feedback on past projects that were often criticized for being too hard.
development_findings.quote: we usually when you make a romhack the criticism is always it's too difficult so i've gotten very wary of difficult

development_findings.summary: The game uses custom decompression, which is balanced against the original game's artificial loading delay. By reducing the delay, they can decompress more complex assets while keeping the total load time the same.
Kaze has considered creating a tech demo by porting Delfino Plaza from Super Mario Sunshine to the RTYI engine to showcase its power and what was theoretically possible on the N64.
development_findings.quote: I am thinking of porting just Delphino Plaza over to this engine and put it on the N64 and be like look the N64 could have played Mario Sunshine.

development_findings.summary: The game features a robust custom sound system, credited to Yoshi Milkman, that creates unique ASMR-like sounds for different surfaces Mario interacts with, such as wood, metal, and glass.
Kaze spontaneously recruited a freelance artist from the chat, providing them with a detailed creative brief for a new enemy: an oil-based version of the 'Frizzlet' ghost.
development_findings.quote: You know these ghosts here? Frizzlet. ... I want something like that, but made out of oil.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a preference for games and sports with clear, unambiguous rules, disliking the 'wishy-washy' nature of games like basketball and soccer. This philosophy likely influences his approach to game design.
context_findings.quote: I like sports that have very... The rules are very distinct. As in like the winning and the losing state. When you are within the rules and when you are out of the rules. It's very distinct from each other.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong opposition to tipping culture, which he views as an unfair system where companies offload the responsibility of paying their employees onto the customer. He prefers transparent, all-inclusive pricing.
context_findings.quote: Why are you asking me for mercy to pay your employees? I am not up for that. I would like to know the price up front. Then I decide whether I want to pay it or not.

context_findings.summary: He reveals that he uses game theory principles, specifically Nash Equilibrium, as a mental model for making decisions in his everyday life, applying it to scenarios ranging from a DoorDash order to a hypothetical hostage situation.
context_findings.quote: If you don't know how to calculate the Nash Equilibrium for anything, how do you even make decisions in your everyday life?

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions he has synesthesia, causing him to associate concepts that are not typically related, such as colors with academic subjects or smells with colors.
context_findings.quote: i do have a lot of synesthesias with like random things like sometimes i mix up letters and numbers or like smells and colors they're just all like one thing

context_findings.summary: He consciously crafts a narrative 'angle' for his YouTube videos to make them more compelling, such as framing technical optimizations as a story about empowering artists on the team.
context_findings.quote: when you make a YouTube video you have to find the angle you have to be like this is why and I think I'm gonna frame it as like look with all this optimization artists have so much more freedom

biobak.summary: Kaze entrusts Biobak with finalizing the artistic vision for levels, relying on him to add textures and props that make the underlying blockout geometry make sense thematically.
biobak.quote: Biobak will justify it in post.

biobak.summary: Kaze defers artistic decisions to Biobak, such as the final details of the large window effect in the underground area.

badub.summary: Badub has composed a song for an enemy or boss referred to as the 'Buzzer'.
He is also creating music for an 'oil bus' (likely oil boss), which is being specifically timed to fit a cutscene.

zeina.summary: Kaze plans to highlight Zeina's expanded role as an artist in an upcoming video, linking her increased contributions to the project's technical optimizations.
zeina.quote: we brought more artists on board which is you and now the game is epic and amazing because we all these optimizations

zeina.summary: Stream interactions, like a discussion about a food delivery order, reveal their personal dynamic as a couple who also collaborates professionally on the game.

key_stories.title: The Window to Above
key_stories.summary: Faced with an undefined underground space, Kaze brainstormed with his stream chat and conceived of a large ceiling window looking up into the main oil rig. This single design choice gave the area a strong thematic identity and visual hook, showcasing his collaborative and iterative creative process.
key_stories.challenge: The newly created underground area for the oil rig level felt disconnected and lacked a clear thematic identity. Kaze himself asked, 'what even is it?'
key_stories.process: While brainstorming on stream, Kaze took inspiration from chat suggestions to envision a large, reinforced glass window in the ceiling. This window would allow the player to look up and see the main structures of the oil rig, giving the underground space context.
key_stories.outcome: The window concept was immediately prototyped and became a core feature of the area, providing a unique visual identity and connecting it thematically to the level above. The final artistic execution was delegated to Biobak.
key_stories.key_quote: what if all of this was like the reinforced window like this is just a window this is just gonna be transparent material

key_stories.title: The Hostage Taker's Dilemma
key_stories.summary: When prompted to tip for a food delivery, Kaze used game theory to deconstruct the situation. He created a payoff matrix live on stream to model the interaction as a 'hostage dilemma,' revealing his deeply analytical and logic-driven approach to everyday life.
key_stories.challenge: A prompt to tip on a DoorDash order sparked a discussion about the logic and fairness of tipping culture.
key_stories.process: Kaze rejected the premise of tipping by reframing it as a 'hostage situation.' He opened MS Paint, drew a game theory payoff matrix, and used the principles of Nash Equilibrium to argue why one should never tip before receiving service, as there is no logical incentive for the other party to provide good service once payment is secured.
key_stories.outcome: The rant provided a deep and humorous insight into Kaze's highly analytical worldview, showing how he applies complex logical frameworks to critique everyday social conventions.
key_stories.key_quote: You think people taking hostages are not smart enough to calculate the Nash Equilibrium for their decision making process? No way.

key_stories.title: Recruiting From the Chat
key_stories.summary: In a moment of spontaneous collaboration, Kaze responded to a query from the chat by offering a freelance job. He provided a detailed brief for a new enemy, showcasing his willingness to directly integrate community talent into the development process.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer in the stream chat, who was an aspiring artist, asked if there was any freelance work available on the project.
key_stories.process: Kaze immediately identified a specific need for the level he was working on. He gave a detailed creative brief on the spot for a new enemy: an oil-based version of the 'Frizzlet' ghost, describing its desired appearance and behavior.
key_stories.outcome: The exchange resulted in a direct commission for a community member to create a needed game asset, demonstrating the project's open and community-integrated development model.
key_stories.key_quote: Actually, yes, I do. There's a lot of assets I need. Do you want to make some? I have an enemy in mind for this.
